div1.head: Jim to Mr. Paul A. Rockwell June 3rd 1916
div1.p: Thanks old pal for talking things over with Grundy. I heard from him yesterday, and he says that I can trust him to get as good a return as possible. I sent him an account of the rotten day we had June 1st. Maybe you can fix up something for yourself for your various connections from story. Don’t know if Kiffin has written you or not.

I left Luxueil late in afternoon of the 31st. Had to fly low on account of clouds. Landed at Toul and spent the night. Mist in morning and didn’t get away until 8.30. A.M. Landed here and the Capt. asked me if I could go out at 12.30. Didn’t know country at all and saw map for first time when I climbed in machine. Was afraid I’d get lost. Lovebury left and then I. Just as Hall was starting he looked up and saw a flock of Boches overhead. Lovebury & I must have passed right under them. Capt G. - Cowden, Prince, Chapman & Hall mounted to attack. Kiffin’s machine was on the bum and he couldn’t go. They got their height and returned to fight the 14 Boches who by this time were over town dropping
(over)
bombs. The Boches used explosive bullets. Capt. G. had a hole blown in tank and came down. Prince had bottom of carlingue blown up and was put out of commission. Cowden’s Mitrailleuse went on the bum. Hall & Chapman chased Boches to line but lost them. While Americans were fighting in air the American Ambulance section I had been with at Pont was working on the ground. _ They were shifted here a little while ago. — Lovell was fine. He stood right smack in middle of square where most bombs were dropping and directed his cars. The boys did well. Many cars were hit. One English chap ^British A. had his arm blown off. Interesting dope for the Yankees having Americans in air and on the ground working against Boche. 40 killed and 200 wounded in town.

Well I lost myself as I felt I would and wandered in general direction of lines. Just before I got to them I looked down and saw a machine. Thought it one of ours of course as I didn’t know about fight. Looked closer and saw the crosses. I shut off my power, reached for the
manet of the Mitrailleuse and piced. I hadn’t the remotest idea about how to go about it. It was the first time I’d shot my Mitrailleuse —first Boche I’d ever seen. I swooped down on him and saw he carried two guns. The fellow in back opened up fire. I took a bead at 50 meters and let go a round. Then my speed carried me off. I turned back but it must have been a punk move for I found myself sighting into the flame of his machine gun. I was right on his level. I then heard his bullets going into my machine. He had a dead bead. I shot at him, turned and then came from other side. As I pressed on manet the machine gun failed to shoot. I turned, dropped the gun, armed it, tried it, nothing doing. Tried again, nothing doing. Then tut-tut-tut back of my head I looked back and saw the German heading for me shooting. I piced and lost him. Looked at machine gun and found roller of cartridges had gone overboard. The radiator was loose as well and I figured bullet had hit the piece. Well then I wondered where I was. In case of
doubt go south west. I did and picked up a canal hoping to follow it up and find home. Tried other canals, crossed big towns. I knew I was below part of the country shown on my map but couldn’t figure which way to go to run across our field. Motor began to go wrong. At 3 I gave up job and decided to land. Picked out a field that looked as if it were made for Aviation. Redressed and skimmed along ground losing speed when there was a hell of a bump and over I went smashing everything. I had hit the field at St. Dizier where everyone smashes. It is covered with grass and has shelves in it. The only way to land is from the direction I didn’t take. Well I felt rotten. Looked the old buss [sic] over and found nine bullet holes in upper and lower wings not a foot from each side of me. He got me well on each side but fortunately didn’t hit between. I’ll have another machine in a coupe of days. Rotten to lose the Boche that way. I could have bawled.

closer.seg: Lovell leaves for Aviation in a few days.
